hawaiian_text: A make ‘o Puali‘i, ho‘i akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o ā hiki i kona makuahine, iā  Pōka‘ī, noho ihola lāua, ‘a‘ohe ‘ai o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ka ‘ai. I ia wā, e noho ana ‘o  ‘Ama‘u he ali‘i no O‘ahu nei, ma Waikīkī kahi i noho ai, hele maila kekahi kanaka no Honouliuli  mai ā hiki ma Waikīkī, e noho ana ke ali‘i. ‘Ōlelo  akula ia: “E ke alii ē\! He ‘oi kahi keiki ‘u‘uku ikaika  loa, ua make kona makua kāne a ua kiola ‘ia kona  po‘o i kai loa, he wahi lō‘ihi loa, ‘elima mile ka  lō‘ihi. A lohe o ‘Ama‘u, aia kona ikaika a make au iā  ia, akā, i ‘ole au e make iā ia ‘a‘ohe ona ikaika. Iā ia  e ‘ōlelo ana ma Waikīkī, ua lohe nō ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo nona.
llama-3.3-70B-Instruct_exl2_6.0bpw-maui_: The death of Puali‘i, and Nāmakaokapāo‘o returned to her mother, Pōka‘ī, and they lived together, but Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not eat the food. At that time, ‘Ama‘u was a chief of O‘ahu, living in Waikīkī, when a man from Honouliuli came to Waikīkī, where the chief was residing. He said: “Oh chief! There's a small, very strong child, whose father died and whose head was chopped off and thrown into the sea, a very deep place, five miles deep. ‘Ama‘u listened, and he was strong and died because of it, but if he hadn't died, he wouldn't have been strong. While speaking in Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo‘o heard these words.

**Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>The death of Puali‘i, and Nāmakaokapāo‘o returned to her mother, Pōka‘ī, and they lived together, but Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not eat the food. At that time, ‘Ama‘u was a chief of O‘ahu, living in Waikīkī, when a man from Honouliuli came to Waikīkī, where the chief was residing. He said: “Oh chief! There's a small, very strong child, whose father died and whose head was chopped off and thrown into the sea, a very deep place, five miles deep. ‘Ama‘u listened, and he was strong and died because of it, but if he hadn't died, he wouldn't have been strong. While speaking in Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo‘o heard these words.</translation>

<commentary>This passage introduces key characters and events that may symbolize the cultural and social upheaval during the early 19th century in Hawai‘i, particularly the shift from the traditional 'Ai Kapu era to the post-1820 missionary influence period.</commentary>

• The narrative may represent the struggle for power and the consequences of violence in ancient Hawaiian society
  – The character of ‘Ama‘u, as a chief of O‘ahu, embodies the traditional ali‘i class, while his encounter with the man from Honouliuli and the story of the strong child may symbolize the disruptions to the existing social hierarchy
  – The reference to the child's father dying and the head being thrown into the sea could represent the loss of traditional values and the disintegration of the old order

• The name Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o can be broken down to reveal its symbolic meaning
  – Nā-: the plural article, indicating multiple or collective
  – maka: eyes
  – o: of, or belonging to
  – ka: the article, indicating a specific thing
  – pāo‘o: a type of shark, or a reference to a group of people
  – The name may signify a collective or group with sharp vision or insight, navigating the challenges of their time

• The historical context of the narrative may be connected to the post-contact period in Hawai‘i
  – The story may reflect the influence of Christian missionaries and the resulting changes to traditional Hawaiian beliefs and practices (as noted by historians like Lilikalā Kame‘eleihiwa, 1992)
  – The character of Nāmakaokapāo‘o, who does not eat the food, may represent a figure who resists or is disconnected from the new cultural or spiritual influences

• The numerical symbolism in the passage, specifically the "five miles deep" reference, could hold cultural significance
  – In Hawaiian culture, numbers often carried symbolic meanings, with five (lima) representing balance, harmony, or completeness (as discussed by Beckwith, 1981)
  – The depth of the sea may also represent the unknown, the spiritual realm, or the subconscious, as suggested by Hawaiian cosmological concepts (like the idea of Kanaloa, the god of the ocean)

• The narrative might be seen as a form of social commentary or critique
  – The story could be interpreted as a warning about the dangers of unchecked power, violence, or the erosion of traditional values (as supported by the work of Hawaiian scholars like Haunani-Kay Trask, 1999)
  – The character of ‘Ama‘u, who dies because of his strength, may serve as a cautionary tale about the consequences of imperial ambitions or the unchecked pursuit of power in ancient Hawaiian society
reference_translation: When Puali‘i died, Nāmakaokapāo‘o went back  to his mother, Pōka‘ī, and the two lived together,  but Nāmakaokapāo‘o had nothing to eat. At that  time, ‘Ama‘u was a chief of O‘ahu in Waikīkī,  where he lived. A man of Honouliuli came to Waikīkī, where the chief was found. The man said,  “Chief, there is a little boy who is amazingly strong.  He killed his father and threw his head in the  ocean a really long distance away, five miles off.”  When ‘Ama‘u heard this, he said, “We’ll see how  strong he is if he kills me. But if he doesn’t kill me,  he isn’t strong at all.” When he said this in Waikīkī,  Nāmakaokapāo‘o heard what he was saying about  him.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14**• From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of  Christianity’s defeat over the ‘Ai Kapu, with   Nāmakaokapāo‘o representing progressive   Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his  mother, Pōka‘ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians’ futile attempts to hold onto ‘Ai Kapu culture.
